none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. D. Rowell, May 21, 1890
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. D. Rowell, May 21, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
IN Re
................................................................................................................................................
V.
................................................................................................................................................

GEO. T. TODD.                                                                                                                               T. D. ROWELL.
OFFICE OF
TODD & ROWELL,
Attorneys and Counselors at Law.
No. 91 Austin Street, Up-stairs in Todd Building.
Geo. T. Todd, Notary Public.                                                                               T. D. Rowell, County Attorney.

No................................................................................................................................................

Jefferson, Texas, May 21 1890

Prof - L. L. McInnis -
College Station Tex
Dear Sir:
You are aware of the fact of
course - that I was an applicant
for the last vacancy on the Board of
Directors of A & M College which said
vacancy was filled by the appoint
ment of Wm Adriance - who by the
way is a most excellent gentleman &
has most likely done more in the capac
ity of Director than I could have done.
Having graduated at A & M C I
have a pride in wanting to be in the
Directory and shall be an applicant
for the next vacancy when ever it shall
take place, be it sooner or later. I have
been informed that you opposed
my appointment before and I wish
at this time to solicit your assis
tance in getting the next vacancy and

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's break this down. First, I'm examining this letterhead: "IN Re...GEO. T. TODD. T. D. ROWELL. OFFICE OF TODD & ROWELL, Attorneys and Counselors at Law. No. 91 Austin Street, Up-stairs in Todd Building. Geo. T. Todd, Notary Public. T. D. Rowell, County Attorney.". It's pretty standard for the era, professional. Then the handwritten date: "Jefferson, Texas, May 21 1890". Good, we're grounded in time. Now, let's dig into the content. The letter is addressed to "Prof. L. L. McInnis - College Station Tex". The handwriting is a bit scrawled in places, but I can decipher it. The salutation, "Dear Sir:". Right, here comes the meat. It begins, "You are aware of the fact of course - that I was an applicant for the last vacancy on the Board of Directors of A & M College which said vacancy was filled by the appointment of Wm Adriance - who by the way is a most excellent gentleman & has most likely done more in the capacity of Director than I could have done." I see some clear points, the writer applied for a directorship at "A & M". It looks like the "A & M" is a hasty ampersand. It seems Wm Adriance was appointed, and the writer acknowledges Adriance's likely superior qualifications. The second paragraph continues, "Having graduated at A & M C I have a pride in wanting to be in the Directory and shall be an applicant for the next vacancy when ever it shall take place, be it sooner or later. I have been informed that you opposed my appointment before and I wish at this time to solicit your assistance in getting the next vacancy and..." So, the writer is a graduate of "A & M C" (presumably the College), desires to be in the "Directory" (likely, in this context, the Board), and is seeking help for the *next* vacancy. The "when ever" is written as two words. It appears the recipient opposed the writer previously. The last line is cut off, but the sentiment is clear: help with the *next* vacancy. Looks like "Directory" as in the board. Here's my transcription, aiming to reflect the original as faithfully as possible: ```html

IN Re                                                                          GEO. T. TODD.                                                                                                                  T. D. ROWELL.
.................................................................................................................................................. OFFICE OF ....................................................................................................
                                       V. &

[Margin: Rowell
May 21, 18[88]]

write this letter for the purpose
of ascertaining, if possible, whether
or not you will use your influ
ence for me - Of course it may
be said that you being under the
Jurisdiction of the Directors as well
as the other members of the faculty, can't,
for that reason take any steps in ad-
vocating the appointment of any par-
ticular person - But I do not suppose
it will be seriously said that mem
bers of the faculty have not joined
in the advocacy or opposition of
different members of the Board of Direc
tors - I do not look forward to
any vacancy soon but simply wish
to know how you will be toward me in
regard to the matter when the time does
come -

Yours truly -
J. C. Rowell

**Analyzing and Transcribing a Handwritten Document** Okay, here's what I've got. This is a handwritten letter, pretty clear cursive with some slant and speed to it, and on lined paper. My task is to accurately transcribe it. First, I need to check the format. The margin note at the top left says "Rowell May 21, 18[...]", likely a filing notation, and I think that date ends in '88' based on what's visible, though it could be 1881 or 1886. Next, I need to see what the letter is about. It seems to be a request for influence concerning an appointment, and it touches on the jurisdiction of directors and faculty. The signature looks like "J. C. Rowell". Considering that Joseph Cummings Rowell was a librarian, and that the text mentions faculty and directors, this fits an academic context, and this looks to me like the right person. I'm now going to transcribe this line by line, keeping to exactly what I see. The margin note reads "Rowell / May 21, 18[88]". The main body of the text starts as: "

write this letter for the purpose
of ascertaining, if possible, whether
or not you will use your influ
ence for me - Of course it may
be said that you being under the
Jurisdiction of the Directors as well
as the other members of the faculty, can't,
for that reason take any steps in ad-
vocating the appointment of any par-
ticular person - But I do not suppose
it will be seriously said that mem
bers of the faculty have not joined
in the advocacy or opposition of
different members of the Board of Direc
tors - I do not look forward to
any vacancy soon but simply wish
to know how you will be toward me in
regard to the matter when the time does
come -

Yours truly -
J. C. Rowell

" I have carefully made some refinements. "influ" is on a split line. The "Jurisdiction" and "Directors" and "Board of Direc" are capitalized. The word "faculty" is lowercase. The word "advocating" is split with "ad-" and "vocating". I will preserve any implied line break in line 3: "influ" and line 14: "Direc" but keep the text as it is. It should read as it is on the paper. I will also make sure the HTML is compliant, so I'll wrap the note in a tag. I will use `
` to preserve the line breaks. So, here's the final output, using the format:
